title: Guava Nails Are Summerâ€™s Freshest Take On Cat-Eye Polish
description: From polka-dot manicures and â€œItalian Summerâ€-inspired nail art to sorbet shades and beach nails, there has been no shortage of incredible nail inspiration for our summer manicures this year. And our latest collective obsession with fruity nails has given rise to an emerging trend to watch for the season ahead: guava nails. While your first thought might be that guava nails are just a new way to describe bubblegum pink, think again. This manicure is actually a shimmering fusion of green and pink thatâ€™s as juicy as the fruit itself. Teamed with a multidimensional finish (think chrome or jelly), the result is a playful manicure that feels fresh and fun. So as our social feeds start to fill with hot takes on this sweet summer nail trend, hereâ€™s everything you need to know about it â€” inspiration included. View this post on Instagram A post shared by ğŸ“PEABODY MA, your nail plug (@polishedbycarrissa) What are guava nails? Some people might refer to a bright pink manicure as â€œguavaâ€, but this summerâ€™s iteration of guava nails is more complex than just paying homage to the flesh of this tropical fruit. â€œThis yearâ€™s trend is inspired by all of the tropical tones of the guava fruit and blends juicy pinks with corals and soft greens to mimic the fruitâ€™s natural appearance,â€ explains session manicurist Ami Streets. Yes, guava nails 2.0 are all about contrast and depth rather than a flat colorblock manicure. View this post on Instagram A post shared by Zola Ganzorigt (@nailsbyzola) The most popular iteration is a cat-eye finish: â€œThe colors are layered using ombrÃ© techniques, jelly finishes, or magnetic cat-eye effects to mimic the fruitâ€™s juicy texture and natural glow,â€ says Streets. Rather than leaning overly neon and bright, this version of guava nails feels undeniably cooler, and there are so many ways to wear it, too. â€œRather than having the cat-eye all over the nails, you can scale it down and apply it just to the middle of the nail or go for a guava nail tip or half moon,â€ suggests London-based nail technician Metta Francis. If youâ€™re heading to the salon for this look, itâ€™s all about layering different colors and finishes for that multidimensional effect. â€œLayer on a soft green magnetic shimmer gel and use a magnet to manipulate the pigment for a cat-eye effect, then apply a pink or coral, sheer jelly formula to the center of the nail for that juicy, fruit-inspired finish,â€ explains Streets. Manicurists are also known to add the centre pop of color by softly dabbing a powder pink pigment or eyeshadow into the nail using a sponge or fluffy brush. â€œThis creates a diffused, blurred effect,â€ says Streets. Finish with an ultra-glossy top coat to seal it all in and create that mirror-glass shine.Â  @polishedbygabbi Guava nail tutorial for summer! author: Mica Ricketts
excerpt: Everyone's asking for guava nails â€” the interesting new way to wear cat-eye polish for summer.
text: Photo: Via @polishedbycarrissa.While your first thought might be that guava nails are just a new way to describe bubblegum pink, think again. This manicure is actually a shimmering fusion of green and pink thatâ€™s as juicy as the fruit itself. Teamed with a multidimensional finish (think chrome or jelly), the result is a playful manicure that feels fresh and fun. So as our social feeds start to fill with hot takes on this sweet summer nail trend, hereâ€™s everything you need to know about it â€” inspiration included.AdvertisementADVERTISEMENTSome people might refer to a bright pink manicure as â€œguavaâ€, but this summerâ€™s iteration of guava nails is more complex than just paying homage to the flesh of this tropical fruit. â€œThis yearâ€™s trend is inspired by all of the tropical tones of the guava fruit and blends juicy pinks with corals and soft greens to mimic the fruitâ€™s natural appearance,â€ explains session manicurist Ami Streets. Yes, guava nails 2.0 are all about contrast and depth rather than a flat colorblock manicure.The most popular iteration is a cat-eye finish: â€œThe colors are layered using ombrÃ© techniques, jelly finishes, or magnetic cat-eye effects to mimic the fruitâ€™s juicy texture and natural glow,â€ says Streets. Rather than leaning overly neon and bright, this version of guava nails feels undeniably cooler, and there are so many ways to wear it, too. â€œRather than having the cat-eye all over the nails, you can scale it down and apply it just to the middle of the nail or go for a guava nail tip or half moon,â€ suggests London-based nail technician Metta Francis.How do you create guava nails?If youâ€™re heading to the salon for this look, itâ€™s all about layering different colors and finishes for that multidimensional effect. â€œLayer on a soft green magnetic shimmer gel and use a magnet to manipulate the pigment for a cat-eye effect, then apply a pink or coral, sheer jelly formula to the center of the nail for that juicy, fruit-inspired finish,â€ explains Streets.AdvertisementADVERTISEMENTManicurists are also known to add the centre pop of color by softly dabbing a powder pink pigment or eyeshadow into the nail using a sponge or fluffy brush. â€œThis creates a diffused, blurred effect,â€ says Streets. Finish with an ultra-glossy top coat to seal it all in and create that mirror-glass shine.Â No UV lamp or want to DIY guava nails yourself at home? Streets suggests following the same layering techniques but switching out the gel formulations for sheer jelly polishes and iridescent formulations. Try Zoya Nail Polish in Meg, $10.95, with Essie Jelly Gloss in Blush Jelly, $13. â€œYou could use a sponge to create an ombrÃ© technique, then finish with a glossy top coat to smooth the finish,â€ says Streets.Into it? The blush pink base and shimmering green French tips are so sweet.Green ShineNail artist Jenny Guthrie layered two different cat-eye gel polishes in â€œweird green colorsâ€ to get this intense green manicure with a subtle pink undertone.Â Metallic TouchesSilver nails are another unexpected summer nail trend, and @tart_nails has layered the trend into this abstract manicure of green jelly and pink marble.Fresh FruitNail technician Kassandra (aka @nailtriip) basically takes a guava and translates it into manicure form here. html:
Photo: Via @polishedbycarrissa.

While your first thought might be that guava nails are just a new way to describe bubblegum pink, think again. This manicure is actually a shimmering fusion of green and pink thatâ€™s as juicy as the fruit itself. Teamed with a multidimensional finish (think chrome or jelly), the result is a playful manicure that feels fresh and fun. So as our social feeds start to fill with hot takes on this sweet summer nail trend, hereâ€™s everything you need to know about it â€” inspiration included.

AdvertisementADVERTISEMENT

Some people might refer to a bright pink manicure as â€œguavaâ€, but this summerâ€™s iteration of guava nails is more complex than just paying homage to the flesh of this tropical fruit. â€œThis yearâ€™s trend is inspired by all of the tropical tones of the guava fruit and blends juicy pinks with corals and soft greens to mimic the fruitâ€™s natural appearance,â€ explains session manicurist Ami Streets. Yes, guava nails 2.0 are all about contrast and depth rather than a flat colorblock manicure.

The most popular iteration is a cat-eye finish: â€œThe colors are layered using ombrÃ© techniques, jelly finishes, or magnetic cat-eye effects to mimic the fruitâ€™s juicy texture and natural glow,â€ says Streets. Rather than leaning overly neon and bright, this version of guava nails feels undeniably cooler, and there are so many ways to wear it, too. â€œRather than having the cat-eye all over the nails, you can scale it down and apply it just to the middle of the nail or go for a guava nail tip or half moon,â€ suggests London-based nail technician Metta Francis.

How do you create guava nails?

If youâ€™re heading to the salon for this look, itâ€™s all about layering different colors and finishes for that multidimensional effect. â€œLayer on a soft green magnetic shimmer gel and use a magnet to manipulate the pigment for a cat-eye effect, then apply a pink or coral, sheer jelly formula to the center of the nail for that juicy, fruit-inspired finish,â€ explains Streets.

AdvertisementADVERTISEMENT

Manicurists are also known to add the centre pop of color by softly dabbing a powder pink pigment or eyeshadow into the nail using a sponge or fluffy brush. â€œThis creates a diffused, blurred effect,â€ says Streets. Finish with an ultra-glossy top coat to seal it all in and create that mirror-glass shine.Â 

No UV lamp or want to DIY guava nails yourself at home? Streets suggests following the same layering techniques but switching out the gel formulations for sheer jelly polishes and iridescent formulations. Try Zoya Nail Polish in Meg, $10.95, with Essie Jelly Gloss in Blush Jelly, $13. â€œYou could use a sponge to create an ombrÃ© technique, then finish with a glossy top coat to smooth the finish,â€ says Streets.

Into it? Here are a few different takes on guava nails to inspire your next manicure.

Juicy Fruits

Think of this chic cat-eye manicure by A.nails Studio as the poolside interpretation of guava nails, thanks to those juicy gel droplets.Â 

Aura Glow

This beautiful gradient nail created by nail artist Glossd uses a bold green and pink color palette for a bright take on the guava trend.

Guava Beach

I love the way that nail artist Angeline (aka @deeznaiilz) has taken inspiration from the hues of a guava fruit and combined it with this summerâ€™s beach nail trend for the ultimate vacation manicure.

AdvertisementADVERTISEMENT

Cat-Eye French

If you prefer a pared-back manicure, then think of this nail look by @cinsclaws as a deconstructed guava. The blush pink base and shimmering green French tips are so sweet.

Green Shine

Nail artist Jenny Guthrie layered two different cat-eye gel polishes in â€œweird green colorsâ€ to get this intense green manicure with a subtle pink undertone.Â 

Metallic Touches

Silver nails are another unexpected summer nail trend, and @tart_nails has layered the trend into this abstract manicure of green jelly and pink marble.

Fresh Fruit

Nail technician Kassandra (aka @nailtriip) basically takes a guava and translates it into manicure form here. The combination of soft green borders, shimmering pink centers, and gel drops truly looks good enough to eat.

This story was originally published on Refinery29 UK.
